Replies.Reply: Written by  Misan Sagay      An intricate piano piece - GEORGE FREDERICK HANDEL...
Hello little girl...Little Dido.
I am your father.
How lovely she is. So much of her mother.
I tried...but how...how could I separate a mother from her child?
And now nature has deprived me of such a dilemma.
Thank you..for taking her.
You may leave us.
Do not be afraid sweet thing. I am to take you to a good life.
She is my blood.
Uncle? You assured me!
I have no wife to take her...In a few hours I am to captain a voyage to the Indies on a longitude experiment.
From there, who knows!!! It is not in my gift to question the King and his Royal Navy.
Sir...
Elizabeth Murray, bring yourself back here this very moment!
But she IS black!
We cannot have another Elizabeth in the household.
Questions, questions, Elizabeth!
No your blood papaa. Sir David Murray. You should not insist on always speaking your mind, you know. You will end up an old maid with only your own company for entertainment!
You little....
Girls! Will you refrain from shrieking like the...bless-ed French!
We shall receive visitors for dinner.
Once again, Dido?
You will not be dining with us, Dido.
Yes. Such are the rules, and you know them well.
Indeed.
Very good connections.
Close your mouth and understand: There shall be no discussions tonight in any languages other than English! No whisperings in gentlemen's ears - not in Latin, Italian...and certainly not French!
My brother is not a man of rash instinct.
Any day now.
She has never played in company!
A gentleman rather like him once paid me much interest.
Do not look at me like that! It was my Mamaa who intervened. I thought he had a very great sense of duty.
Engaged!
Love?
And port!!
Let her enjoy his society.
Mabel! Freshen the flowers!
I learned yesterday that Mr Davinier is in town.
He never married. Cousin Marjorie wrote me last year, that he had died after a long illness.
I cannot see...!
Elizabeth - some advice.     Wait for no man, dear!
A greater pity you rejected her.
The niece of the Marquess of Winchester. Mr James Ashford is to marry the niece of the Marquess of Winchester.
I am reading it here.
What in God's name have you done!!
A detail you chose NOT to share.
Captain Sir John Lindsay, do you find me a fool? She is a MULATTO!
You keep in mind my position..?
Then have some sense of propriety boy...and understand what you are asking.
How do we raise her...?
She takes your name?
Captain Sir John Lindsay.
Do you recognise him?
D'you see here...? This..this is your grandfather, Sir Alexander Lindsay of Evelick.
I am here too....do you see?
Yes...I am William Murray, First Earl of Mansfield.
Now...do you see this man? He is my nephew...do you understand...?
...your uncle - Sir David Murray.
You are a sharp little one. He is The Seventh Viscount Stormont...
...to inherit everything that we are standing on when I am gone.
Indeed. He discovered her mother aboard a captured Spanish slave ship. He was charged with conveying it back to these shores, he tells me.
He has been at sea, six years.
Elizabeth was much in need of a companion.
We shall say that in accordance with her birthright, she is entitled to live beneath this roof.
Impossible. Any match her..'other origins' may attract would surely disgrace her and the family rank.
I have reason to speak with you alone, Dido.
You have done no such thing.
I have not past experience in the ways of breaking grave news to you.
Yes.   I know.
Dinner with guests is a formal proceeding, Dido - we simply cannot impose the disregard of those formalities upon visitors.
My dear...I wish it were so simple. Finances may go some way -
BUT after dinner...when formality is of less consequence...well your presence can raise no defendable objections.
Dido, you know the rules of propriety. Far better than Elizabeth, if I am frank.
The law, Lady Ashford. It is to be interpreted - not merely administered.
Your husband of all people knows this.
It is a fuss over the bread and butter of a great many in these isles. A great many, Lady Ashford.
Dido...my dear.
May I present to you the second of my nieces - Miss Dido Lindsay.
She must not delude herself. Such decisions are not hers to make.
She has no reason. Hers is an inheritance that renders her free of the usual inducements to marry.
Mr Davinier, I believe you have already had the pleasure.
Decide what?
The man is to be paid a fortune.
Dido, you are to simply sit still. Not a challenging task!
As you always are - right beside one another.
Not now, no! You may return the books to the library.
Upon her husband's death a widow may receive....
Hummm...
Yours are grand ambitions.
What is the purpose of the law in your eyes, Mr Davinier?
Example.
It is one of the few trades acceptable to a gentleman.
You aspire to the judiciary?
Noble if not pompous! A country lawyer, you may make - perhaps! If you pay every regard to what you are taught - but you have neither the rank nor finances for any more!
I beg your pardon?
You believe you are worthy of such considerations? Such are your capabilities?
The Reverend has requested I take his son into my tutorage, Dido.
What do you think?
I cannot disagree.
Justitia fiat, ruat coelum, Mr Davinier - Let justice be done, though the heavens may fall.
It does.
necessity'. If the cargo was spoiled...
the ship - as the captain contends.
The ship's journey was thwarted by impossible weather conditions -
Then do you know what a hundred thirsty slaves are capable of? I can tell you no man happily disposes of his cargo, even in the face of rebellion!
So now tell me - were you to dock at port with barely a piece of merchandise left to trade -
Elizabeth is to come out.
You understand the ways of this world for a female, Dido.
Dido, you are well taken care of -
You may attend London together to keep Elizabeth company and save the pain of a few weeks separation.
You are not to be denied, Dido.
These are the keys to the house.
Lady Mary is too old to continue in charge of the house.
You may assume her duties on your return. A most respectable position for an unmarried Mansfield Lady.
Punishing you!! Dido, you are most cherished. Most loved. Why ...why would you say such a thing?
Because what?
You told her they were wantonly drowned.
You have entered my home and utterly taken advantage of the confidential matters afforded you.
Her precious care is in my hands and I will decide when she is ready for such realities. Not the son of a vicar! A vicar who, incidently purchased his living from me!
Do so!
WHAT, Mr Davinier!
Mr Davinier.
A word to the wise. Find yourself in her vicinity again, and you will rue the day you cast eyes on me.
I beg your pardon?
She is free and under our protection.
And paid a very respectable wage.
Fraud?
That would depend on to whom you may speak.
Do you speak on my behalf, Dido?
Makes sense. Dido is beginning to sound very much like him.
Which one?
Spit it out.
I will neither be pressured from the inside - or the outside.
How? RULES are in place to dictate how we live - were that not the case, I would not have had the mandate to give shelter to my nephew's child.
She is his blood - MINE! And rightfully had entitlement to grow up on the family estate.

The parliamentarians may challenge me - let them! I can tell you all, if the law supports the Zong's slave owners as strongly as Murray blood runs through Dido Belle's veins - make no mistake - the insurers will be forced to pay up!
Oh?
Is that so?
I have had reason to speak with Lord Ashford.
We are.
You once asked me, who would look after her when we are gone.
Where is everybody, Mabel? The carriages are gone.
And Dido also?
Well is she, or isn't she?
This man's ambitions include you.
...I have EVERY right...!
I know there is a lady in Belsize who is waiting to be your wife.
Love? You claim love....??
Captain Sir John Lindsay would never behave like this because he was never HERE!...You are destroying your possibilities with the only gentleman who will consider you.
Is that what you want?
world a better place'!...
He is laughing at us! His childish campaign simply adds to my already rampant ridicule in the gossip pamphlets and now...!
I never broke the rules.
why I simply do not want to see her diminished.
Lady Ashford there is little point in repetition...
It will hang at Kenwood.
Why should that surprise you?
What are you reading?
You find yourself in such writing?
What is it that you want, Dido?
You did not become Lord Mayor through being a coward.
Why does it matter to you so?
It is for property!
Dido.
The carriage begins to move off.   JOHN walks alongside it.
She is not a slave.
This is not about Miss Lindsay.
Mr Davinier, the world is a devastating place. You must learn to protect your emotions if you are to prevent matters of both law..and love from devastating you.
journey, killing them once on shore, and at their destination...depriving the slave owners of any compensation.
captain and crew from certain death, when the extended journey threatened shortage of drinking-water.

Let me be clear, loss of water on a ship constitutes a singularly dangerous affair - insurrection of thirsty and hostile slaves at its extreme - and an impossible task to share diminished water reserve, among all those living, at best. Each implies severe threat to the lives of the seamen. In such circumstances our law is transparent and equivocal -
the slaves...A popular fashion of transportation that is known for causing death and disease.
Captain's part, and further, weigh as his own risk. An extended journey - one in which the destination is overshot may also be viewed as the captain's own mismanagement.

It is not legal...to discharge lives from a ship into the waters, to prevent those lives dying on land, and to facilitate insurance compensation. Whether they be the lives of horses... or human beings ...slaves or otherwise - It is not legal, neither is it right.

Further, the claim of shortage of water is illegitimate shown by the evidence put forward. To my mind, it is clear a fraud has been committed in claiming insurance on slaves who were...drowned solely for financial gain.

It is my opinion, that the state of slavery is so odious a position that nothing may support it. This case has displayed with searing clarity the depravity of any such nation whose choice is to practice it. You may be certain that I have laboured over my judgement and statements today and am in full understanding of all of the ramifications. Justice be done,though the heavens may fall.
I find in favour of the insurers and overturn the decision of the lower court. I order a retrial.
I am fully aware, Dido.
You are a man of conviction.
Then your efforts are not in vain.
I have not changed my mind. She is to marry a gentleman.
He is...indeed...Dido.
And that is why he ought to have a job befitting one.
If you would Mr Davinier, I would like you to attend my chambers in the morning. There are matters I would like you to assist me with.
And if you think it a good idea...I wish to facilitate your entry to the Inns of Court.
such as yours are clearly deserving of such considerations.
She...she is black.
That is simply impossible.
What has she been named?
We...we will call her Dido.
Good Lord, she is thin. Mary, find her something to eat.
Born on English soil?
for the woman.
Well, he clearly saw to their wellbeing. The child is not altogether uncivilized.
So...now we have two nieces in our guardianship.
And that is what we shall say when questions are asked of us?
her colour be placed? Below or above her Murray bloodline?
May she dine with us?
Marriage?
And when we are no longer here? No husband - who will take care of her?
Dido!...
What a wretched countenance!
What a great pity  LADY MANSFIELD and LADY MARY feign nonchalance.
Our young gentlemen guests shall miss you, Elizabeth.
And most agreeable by all accounts!
For that we are all grateful.
Not quite.
Hers was a most diligent governess.
The liberty of asking her to play! And when he can have no better intentions towards her.
Can he??
...His family name will, no doubt, entice her to take him seriously.
Indeed, it is Elizabeth who needs to secure her bread and butter.
Mr Davinier, will you be joining us for dinner?
Of course - as you wish.
Really, Mary?
HE is engaged, you know?
Mr Beresford's daughter.
We are to attend London for the Season.
Dido is not.
You are to meet as many gentlemen as possible, before we make the match.
A gentleman of good breeding is unlikely to form any serious attachment to Dido, and a man without, will lower her position in society.
Lord knows I will need you both to keep each other out of trouble.
Light the fires for dinner, will you, Thomas.
Promise me you will change that vulgar teal paint, if you ever become lady of this home. It is positively wanting, Elizabeth.
Lady Ashford.
And the gentlemen? Mr James?
Which has gone to my head already!
I am not at ease with this.
People will think she has no family!
It's almost dark!
She is.
Do I sense that an address is finally to be made?
Lady Ashford, may I...
Good heavens, Lord Mansfield has arrived a day early!
Oh will you please stop!
This is a vulgar subject to be discussing at breakfast  DIDO and LORD MANSFIELD are locked in a stand-off.
And I to Lady Ashford.
Are we in agreement?
You need worry about nothing.
Shooosh!
Quiet, Elizabeth!
She has agreed! O...
LADY MARY wipes a tear, discreet as ELIZABETH stands, rooted.
We are to make many calls today, Elizabeth. Acquainting oneself with the most eligible gentleman is not light business.
Will you join us, Dido?
Dido?
Oh dear! Unwell? And just as we are to announce your news!
How charming. Is that not charming, Elizabeth? And tell me, are you an only son?
SIX! Goodness!...all..?
Is that not a most fascinating display?
Indeed, Baroness Vernon.
Now I have checked and he has no London home, but I have good information he achieves an income no less than four thousand a year!
I shall make arrangements.
Are you unwell, my dear?
You said something identical, once.
That you wanted to change the world! Quite some time before you entered your chambers, of course.
Desperate to seal your position among the establishment but always a little too radical for them.
Did you not? You simply became powerful enough to make new ones.
I always felt you already loved me when I gave you my hand. Not that you said it but... something in the way you looked at me.
in his eye...without knowing -
It is possible that even you cannot fight change, my darling...
Do you love her?
That shall render your future mother-in-law ecstatic, Dido.
That is enough!
Smooth your dress, young lady!
Mr Vaughan, how kind of you to come.
Her mother is dead! My wishes may not be orthodox but they ARE necessary!
I beg you, uncle...love her - as I would, were I here.
And ensure that she is in receipt of all that is due to her as a child of mine.
What is right can never be impossible.
She is Belle...after her mother.
I am not ashamed.
Little Belle - sweet child...
My wish is to keep you...keep you with me...but a ship...it is no place for one so precious as you.
In these walls, yours will be a life equal to my blood.
You will not understand in this moment, but hold this in your heart...you are loved...Just as I loved your mother.
Are you...a nee-gro?
I heard them talking.
Papaa M?
Like you, Aunt Mary? That is what the maids say?
Two thousand pounds a year?
Then you are an heiress! He has left you your fortune!
He must have loved you, Dido.
My father's new wife wishes him to leave me not a thing, and he obliges her.
I think he might have loved me more if Mamaa had not died.
Dido - with such a dowry you may marry into any good family you wish.
Visitors? Who ever bothers to visit us here?
May we wear the new silks?
There you are. I have been searching for you!
I would rather dine with Dido!
suggestion of a sensitive man'.
He is the eldest - to inherit the entire Ashford fortune. He is also to inherit from his uncle -
Lady Ashford herself. She seems rather despondent at her brother's robust constitution.
Dido! You are not to be a coquette with him! You already have your fortune!
Good Lord! They are appraising me!
A portrait? Are you sure?
Good Lord. How...truly wonderful.
But what, Dido?
Papaa's new student.
Someone to keep you company while you take Papaa's dictation, Dido.
Truth is, there have been more of your sex at Kenwood this week, than I've previously seen in all my entire life!
On the contrary!
Mr Davinier?
Is he?
The carriage-maker! He might have set his sights a little higher!
There you are!
We are requested. You - drawing room.
Oh!
But she is not merely my cousin, Mamaa, she is my sister. I cannot attend London without her!
I am sorry, Dido. So very sorry.
John Davinier is leaving very early today!
Do you think I may see Mr James in town?
I could fall in love with such a man, Dido.
Aren't you quietly relieved?
That you shan't be at the caprice of some silly Sir and his fortune!
The rest of us haven't the choice!
We are but their property.
Oh Dido look - Mr James has made me a boat and it has capsized.
What is that to mean Mr James?
Are you really to defy Papaa?
I do hope you know how well I think of you.
Then I hope, Sir, you plan to honour your attentions...as not to would leave me looking... quite foolish.
Hardly, Dido!
Whatever did happen in the end, Aunt Mary? With your gentleman friend.
Oh Aunt Mary...
What are you doing?
Agreed?
Dido...was there any message for me?
What does it feel like Dido? To be engaged?
Should we not wait a day or two -
Urghhh! What if I shall never find someone so...so incomparably suitable...and wealthy?!
Oh Dido! He understood me.
And whenever...whenever...
I am convinced his affections were growing...and I feel certain of my own love.
Dido! You stop it, won't you?
Then what better right do you have to name what I am feeling than me?
Mamaa, Mr Vaughan approaches.
Oh most certainly.
Oh!
Oh!..Mr James!
Lady Ashford, you had not mentioned Mr James was to attend!
I have heard nothing from him, since Vauxhall, Dido. I was certain an announcement was to be made any day...that he meant it this time!
You would do that? For me?
Dido...
I have been of the mind these last few days...that it is my little means that has delayed James in making his approach.
Then I cannot thank you enough.
I will ask Papaa to write immediately to Lady Ashford.
No?
Then your gift comes with conditions.
What then?
Why should you say such a thing?
You are a liar!
I don't know - but do you not see? Have you never been able to see? He would never touch you...!
You are beneath him!
Yes. You...you are...
DIDO is winded, but relieved.
Have you never wondered why you are not permitted to eat with our guests?
Don't you dare say a word.
Why! Why do they ALWAYS do that!!
Men! They leave and never come back!
I saw you with him, that day.   At the pleasure garden.
I wanted you to tell me. To trust me.
I simply hope he is worth it.
I have thought of nothing else but showing you Aunt Mary's chrysanthemums, Mr Vaughan.
You too Mamaa.
Elizabeth's papa.
Bette! No...no surprises Bette!
Have I wronged you, Papaa?
I thought I should one day have the opportunity to make his better acquaintance.
He did not know me.
Then it is her cruelty you should lament, Bette, not his stupidity.
I...I think love must be a very complicated thing.
Or leave... except the dead!
Beds...Aunt Mary. We should prepare some extra beds... in case our visitors are to stay...
I will do your hair, Bette. Oh say we may wear them, Aunt Mary.
Yes of course. But I may join after dinner, may I not?
She is a most disagreeable...
Papaa...how...how may I be too high in rank to dine with the servants and too low to dine with my family?
But...Papaa, am I not..'wealthy', now...an heiress? Surely that changes matters...
As you wish, sir.
Wimbridge!
There are poachers wandering...!
Sir, I do not believe we have been introduced!
You shall not interrupt him at dinner, Wimbridge!
How do you know?
He has much to recommend him. And a second fortune in life should please any wife.
Are you suggesting I now condescend to a gentleman without means, Bette?! What should good society think of us!
Well...
Papaa...?
Yes...Aunt Mary has confirmed it.
But...but...
Papaa...should he not have wished to SEE me before deciding?
I am sorry...I did not know you...
If he should...should WANT to paint me!
But...
Next...next to Elizabeth...?
How should any male know the ways of a lady when he has not even mastered the ways of a gentleman?
Papaa, may we do this in private!
Papaa...!
I neither spoke for or against you - since neither is my place.
Mr Davinier, my cousin, Elizabeth.
Papaa has never taken a pupil, you realise?
Mr Davinier, what...what is the importance of the Zong... why is the case before Papaa's court, the supreme court...?
I...I am aware of that.
Oh. You said those who were drowned.
But...why?
Thank you.
That is not correct.
And well you might be - when the son of clergy is permitted to the table before a lady of the house.
No. It's a statement of mine!
But...what, Aunt Mary?
Wait...
I appear the only one to have just learned of this affair?
Why do you judge me so?
It is a fact that I have contemplated on the matter for many hours, and I...I do not think the slaves could have been drowned in the way you say.
Mr Davinier...please. Tell me.
Do not render me your amusement.
And what...what is that?
But the insurers are appealing.
Thank you.
Papaa.
LORD MANSFIELD stares back at her.
But why?
And me?
Papaa...
Papaa, please!
No! I am not Lady Mary. I am not an unwanted maid!
Are...are you punishing me?
Because...
Because ...
Perhaps.
Bette, you could feel no such sentiment for you should either end poor or... broken hearted.
Relieved?
You are so beautiful, Bette.
Mabel, I am fine - thank you!
What a dreadful shame.
Thank you.
I should be delighted, Mr Oliver!
Ah now how do I know this is not just another tactic in your battle to conquer?
Despite...such pronounced protestations from your brother?
What a lovely sound.
Really? You are much of the conqueror Mr Oliver.
Mr Davinier. How...how nice to see you.
Forgive me - Mr Ashford, may I present to you...Mr Davinier.
He is the son of our Vicar at Hampstead, and was..well, almost father's pupil...
Elizabeth and Mamaa are here...
I did not have the chance to see you before you left...Mr Davinier ...to convey my apologies.
Your pupilage. Father would never have ended it...you...you never would have had to leave Kenwood were it not...
What are you doing here in London Mr Davinier?
Not what you wished for.
Where are my manners? I trust the future Mrs Davinier is well.
I have tried to keep up - with the Zong. These past weeks.
What price, a worthless Negro.
But that would require a change of law. I know nothing but...
No. It is more than that. It's the shame of a law that would uphold a financial transaction upon that atrocity.
I have never heard anyone speak like you.
No we cannot risk it.
Good bye, Mr Davinier.
Quite.
I..I am terribly sorry. I thought I saw the others, I went after them....and found myself lost.
Is Mabel a slave?
Is-Mabel-a-slave!
O! Like me!
How is the fraud appeal Papaa?
The marine insurance. It is a Fraud case, is it not?
solely to claim insurance because it was too diseased to achieve a good price at market? If not fraud, then what?
Excuse me.
Mr Oliver.
Yes. Indeed it is.
Good Lord, Mr Oliver! Your ...your wife? Mrs Ashford?!
...I cannot...
I cannot...think of anything ...more wonderful!
Mamaa, we are engaged!
It is a good thing, is it not, Mamaa?
won't be long.
Perfect, Bette - pefect.
Papaa.
Thank you.
I..I am terribly light headed this morning, Mamaa. I should like to take rest if it would not displease you.
Harry! Harry!
Harry, I need your help. I need you to take me somewhere.
I shall not be alone, I shall be with you.
Please - Harry. If you don't take me, I shall be forced to go alone.
Mr Davinier.
No...It would be dangerous.
Oh Mr Davinier...I am so proud of you. I am so proud of what you are doing and...achieving.
At least thirty per cent of insurers are with you! It is a start. It is a real start.
I have something to show you.
but...here...I found these in Papaa's library.
Papaa's notes on the ship's log.
And they did not! They either ignored the possibilities, or they were never in need.
What is the alternative?
Just as in life, we are no better in paintings...
Afraid?
Do not feel ashamed.
we are but their property.
Gentlemen's. We women are but the property of gentlemen. That is the way it is, in law and in life, is it not?
And it came into my head that I have been blessed with freedom twice over? As a negro and as a woman?
Or have I?
I remember my Papaa's eyes. They were kind, gentle... a little like yours...
I mean...in colour. Grey.
He showed me much love, though I knew him only a few hours.
She is a ghost in my life -
I had never felt it.
I am to marry, shortly - Mr Ashford.
He is amiable and of good family.
The alternative is to replace Lady Mary in her responsibilities at Kenwood.
Papaa did not trust I could achieve a match that might raise my rank - or even equal it.
Is anyone home, Mabel?
Oh Bette, stop it! It is NOT love!!
No.
Oh, Mr James, your manners are as poor as your brother's finances.
That is painful, sir.
It is not in my repertoire to keep company with beasts.
How dare you? HOW DARE YOU!
Is she not terribly disappointed that you will not return to Hampstead?
Completely. Elizabeth, always asked the questions for me...
...I find myself unable to sleep. Papaa is to finally speak in a few days and...well...

And yet if he does...stand up...IF he speaks the words and condemns the trade...The Lord Chief Justice of England...it may be impossible for the slave laws of England and its colonies to remain absolute. Is that correct?
Then he is not a man of his word.
I will help you find the kindest most wonderful of husbands.
And I shall ask Papaa to use a portion of my inheritance for your dowry.
Bette, anything for you!
I think you may be right.
Bette...?
No!
James Ashford is not kind. He is not a man to give your life or dowry to.
No!
I am trying...trying to make you see. He is not... appropriate!
He does not desire you, Bette!
He hurt me.
Why...why would I lie to you?
Bette...
I am beneath him??
What! Tell me! What am I, Bette?
My mother and father never married - you are correct. But my father acknowledged me as his child.
It is yours who refuses to legitimise your position, Bette -
Papaa...?
NO! STOP! Papaa, you must stop!
Go John.   You do not deserve this.
Captain Sir John Lindsay would never have behaved like this.
I won't.
Who, Bette?
You said nothing.
I should have.
You view my circumstances as unfortunate, though I cannot claim even a portion of the misfortune of those to whom I most closely resemble.
My greatest misfortune would be to marry into a family who will carry me as their shame - as I have been required to carry my own mother.
Her apparent crime, to be born negro, and mine - to be the evidence.
Why did I, slave, beyond my lot aspire..
Will it?
Why should it not?
Poetry. A gentleman named Thomas Day. He speaks of a slave who agreed to marry a free woman.
I don't know that I find myself anywhere. I have no place that I may claim.

Papaa, you enabled every rule, but you had to overlook just as many to raise me within good society. And what if there were not a rule Papaa? What if that rule that allowed you to take me did not exist? Would you have returned me to the slums?
You are courageous. When it comes to the matters you believe in, society is inconsequential.
Fine! Then step down and allow me to take the reigns.
No!
You may not blame Mr Davinier ...My attendance today is absolutely at my own volition ...for matters which concern me.
And Mr Davinier is not a gentleman?
My affections are with him, Papaa.
Of course. He sees what I see.
It is not. It is not all that is before you Mr Davinier...
I love you...for all that you are, and with all..all that I am.
...for it is the power of God unto salvation to every one that believeth. So saith Christ the Lord. Amen.
Amen.
What excellent French! Though I have not an idea of what you said.
...a lady.
I must say, the entire country barely breathes awaiting your judgement on this appeal.
What a lot of fuss over dead cargo.
Good Lord - the negro! She really is...
I hadn't expected her to look so...black.
You will refrain from any intercourse with the negress.
Lord and Lady Mansfield may find it fascinating to have a Lady Mulatto running around their household, but I will not have one running around mine!
Although exceptions can be made.
I mean to say, if that is your inclination.

my Aunt?

...But religion cannot be the only guardian of our morality.
And failing that does the law not have a duty?

Do the bench and parliament not have a duty to uphold and create the laws, to set the precedents that progress our morality, not retard it! If not to protect us from others, then to protect us from ourselves! Laws that allow us to diminish the humanity of anybody, are not laws - they are frameworks for crime.

A constitution can never be finite - surely as humanity evolves so too must its laws. And frankly I really do not care if you as an individual are without character or conscience - But a land whose laws contain neither - whose laws sanction not control the barbarous among its citizens - that is a country whose hope is lost.
